coredata.dc:title: Discovery of a novel species, Theileria haneyi n. sp., infective to equids, highlights exceptional genomic diversity within the genus Theileria: implications for apicomplexan parasite surveillance
coredata.prism:copyright: Published by Elsevier Ltd on behalf of Australian Society for Parasitology.
coredata.dc:creator: Knowles, Donald P.
Kappmeyer, Lowell S.
Haney, Darrell
Herndon, David R.
Fry, Lindsay M.
Munro, James B.
Sears, Kelly
Ueti, Massaro W.
Wise, Lauren N.
Silva, Marta
Schneider, David A.
Grause, Juanita
White, Stephen N.
Tretina, Kyle
Bishop, Richard P.
Odongo, David O.
Pelzel-McCluskey, Angela M.
Scoles, Glen A.
Mealey, Robert H.
Silva, Joana C.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A novel apicomplexan parasite was serendipitously discovered in horses at the United States – Mexico border. Phylogenetic analysis based on 18S rDNA showed the erythrocyte-infective parasite to be related to, but distinct from, Theileria spp. in Africa, the most similar taxa being Theileria spp. from waterbuck and mountain zebra. The degree of sequence variability observed at the 18S rDNA locus also suggests the likely existence of additional cryptic species. Among described species, the genome of this novel equid Theileria parasite is most similar to that of Theileria equi, also a pathogen of horses. The estimated divergence time between the new Theileria sp. and T. equi, based on genomic sequence data, is greater than 33 million years. Average protein sequence divergence between them, at 23%, is greater than that of Theileria parva and Theileria annulata proteins, which is 18%. The latter two represent highly virulent Theileria spp. of domestic cattle, as well as of African and Asian wild buffalo, respectively, which differ markedly in pathology, host cell tropism, tick vector and geographical distribution. The extent of genome-wide sequence divergence, as well as significant morphological differences, relative to T. equi justify the classification of Theileria sp. as a new taxon. Despite the overall genomic divergence, the nine member equi merozoite antigen (EMA) superfamily, previously found as a multigene family only in T. equi, is also present in the novel parasite. Practically, significant sequence divergence in antigenic loci resulted in this undescribed Theileria sp. not being detectable using currently available diagnostic tests. Discovery of this novel species infective to equids highlights exceptional diversity within the genus Theileria, a finding with serious implications for apicomplexan parasite surveillance.

Phylogenetic analysis
18S rDNA
Equi merozoite antigen superfamily
Equids

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Phylogeny of Theileria 18S rDNA sequences. More than 12 18S rDNA sequences in GenBank are assigned to Theileria equi. They are arranged into three distinct clades, A-C. Clade B contains T. equi Ho-79 Florida (T. equi FL), the reference T. equi isolate (navy blue); whether or not the sequence from a South African isolate here is a bona fide T. equi sequence is uncertain. Each of the other two clades, A and C, likely contain more than one species. One of these species is Theileria haneyi n. sp., whose sequences are shown in red. The most closely related 18S rDNA sequences to T. haneyi n. sp. were obtained from the mountain zebra and the waterbuck. In contrast to all the sequences named “T. equi”, all 18S rDNA sequences from Theileria parva isolates are identical to each other (light orange), with the exception of one sequence (Allsopp et al., 1993) which differs by one nucleotide. Closely related Theileria annulata is presented in sea green. The phylogenetic relationship was reconstructed using maximum likelihood; nodes with ≥75% bootstrap support are shown.

Intra-erythrocytic (merozoite) forms of Theileria equi (A-D) and Theileria haneyi n. sp. (E-H). Giemsa-stained blood film of equine erythrocytes from H196(S) (T. equi) and H248(S) (T. haneyi n. sp.) infected with T. equi or T. haneyi n. sp. at 14 days p.i. Arrows indicate forms (merozoites and Maltese crosses) within the infected erythrocytes. Merozoites may be spherical or pyriform (pear shaped) (Mehlhorn and Schein, 1998). Maltese crosses are characterized by an arrangement of four merozoites. Arrows in A-D for T. equi indicate different phases of merozoites and Maltese crosses. Similarly, arrows in E-F for T. haneyi n. sp. indicate different phases of merozoites and Maltese crosses. Width and length measurements of merozoites were performed on individual masses of Maltese crosses. Bar = 10 µm.

Phylogenetic and synteny analyses of the equi merozoite antigen (EMA) multigene family. Phylogeny of Theileria EMA genes. Theileria orientalis, Theileria parva and Theileria annulata contain only a single-copy ema gene. Nine copies are found in Theileria equi and Theileria haneyi n. sp.; the expansion pre-dates the split of these two taxa. Six of the nine copies have clear orthologs – EMA 2, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9. Three of the nine copies in T. equi – EMA 1, 3 and 4 – have no clear orthologs in T. haneyi n. sp. A species-specific expansion appears to have occurred in T. haneyi n. sp. as EMA 10, 11 and 12 have no clear orthologs in T. equi. The phylogenetic relationship was reconstructed using maximum likelihood; nodes with ≥75% bootstrap support are shown.

Distribution of amino acid sequence divergence (d AA) between Theileria haneyi n. sp. and Theileria equi orthologs, compared with that between Theileria parva and Theileria annulata. A set of 1,320 proteins with orthologs in T. haneyi n. sp. (Th), T. equi (Te), T. parva (Tp) and T. annulata (Ta) was identified, such that all were single copy genes and identical in size in all four species. Amino acid sequence divergence was calculated between the two pairs of species Te-Th (red) and between Tp-Ta (blue). The modal value of d AA (as well as mean and median) was higher between T. equi – T. haneyi n. sp. than between T. parva – T. annulata, suggesting that the divergence time between T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp. is larger than the one that separates T. parva and T. annulata.

Phylogenetic analysis of 223 protein coding genes found in nine apicomplexan parasites. The phylogenetic placement of Theileria haneyi n. sp. was confirmed using 223 protein-coding genes predicted by GeneMark-ES using single-copy homologs across five species of Theileria (including T. haneyi n. sp.) and four species of Babesia.

Protein divergence between Theileria haneyi n. sp. and Theileria equi (Th-Te) relative to the divergence between Theileria parva and Theileria annulata (Tp-Ta). Each data point represents a protein encoded by a single-copy gene in each of the four species, and corresponds to the amino acid (AA) sequence divergence in each pairwise comparison. Slowly evolving proteins appear near the origin of the axes while rapidly evolving ones are furthest away. The error associated with each Th-Te and Tp-Ta divergence estimate is shown (horizontal and vertical bars on each point, respectively), as is the total least squares (TLS) regression fit (solid line) and its 95% confidence intervals (dotted lines). This linear fit explains ∼47% of the variation in the data (n = 1,109 proteins). The slope of the line, α , is an estimate of the age of the lineage Tp-Ta relative to the age of Th-Te, and shows that the split between T. parva and T. annulata occurred more recently than that between T. haneyi n. sp. and T. equi (α = 0.77).
Initial sequencing primers used to confirm presence/absence of ema family members in the Theileria haneyi genome by direct BAC sequencing.

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: ND, not done because there was no BAC coverage of the locus.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Data used to determine the age of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of Theileria equi and Theileria haneyi. Its age ranges between 33.1 million years (MY) and 61.4 MY, depending on the rate of synonymous substitution used.

row.entry: Age of species divergence (MY) (calibrated with two rates of synonymous substitution)

T. parva – T. annulata
a (d S = 0.675)

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: a
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: The absolute age of the Theileria parva – Theileria annulata (Tp-Ta) split is estimated by calibrating nucleotide divergence in synonymous sites between the two species (median d S = 0.675; based on 2,460 orthologous gene pairs) with the rate of synonymous substitution per site per year estimated for metazoans (∼8.1 × 10−9) and for invertebrates (1.5 × 10−8). Accordingly, T. parva and T. annulata last shared a common ancestor between (d S/subst_rate/2_branches * MY = 0.675/1.5 × 10−8 × 106/2) 25.5 and (0.675/8.1 × 10−9 × 106/2) 47.3 million years ago (MYA).

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: b
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: The MRCA of T. haneyi n. sp. and T. equi is estimated from its age relative to the MRCA of Tp-Ta (1/α), and hence is estimated to fall between (25.5/α) 33 to (47.3/α) 61 MYA (see Section 2.11).

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Outcomes of blood transfers among horses used to define Theileria haneyi n. sp.

ce:article-footnote.ce:note-para: Note: Nucleotide sequence data reported in this paper are available in GenBank under accession numbers KU647704–KU647710.

head.ce:title: Discovery of a novel species, Theileria haneyi n. sp., infective to equids, highlights exceptional genomic diversity within the genus Theileria: implications for apicomplexan parasite surveillance

ce:list-item.ce:para: Genomic diversity between Theileria equi and Theileria haneyi is greater than Theileria parva and Theileria annulata.
Divergence time between T. equi and T. haneyi is greater than 33 million years.
Genomic diversity between T. equi and T. haneyi is not reflected in differences in pathogenesis.
The Equi merozoite antigen superfamily, present in T. equi, is also present in T. haneyi.
Diversity of Theileria in equids is exceptional and presents consequences for parasite surveillance.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A novel apicomplexan parasite was serendipitously discovered in horses at the United States – Mexico border. Phylogenetic analysis based on 18S rDNA showed the erythrocyte-infective parasite to be related to, but distinct from, Theileria spp. in Africa, the most similar taxa being Theileria spp. from waterbuck and mountain zebra. The degree of sequence variability observed at the 18S rDNA locus also suggests the likely existence of additional cryptic species. Among described species, the genome of this novel equid Theileria parasite is most similar to that of Theileria equi, also a pathogen of horses. The estimated divergence time between the new Theileria sp. and T. equi, based on genomic sequence data, is greater than 33 million years. Average protein sequence divergence between them, at 23%, is greater than that of Theileria parva and Theileria annulata proteins, which is 18%. The latter two represent highly virulent Theileria spp. of domestic cattle, as well as of African and Asian wild buffalo, respectively, which differ markedly in pathology, host cell tropism, tick vector and geographical distribution. The extent of genome-wide sequence divergence, as well as significant morphological differences, relative to T. equi justify the classification of Theileria sp. as a new taxon. Despite the overall genomic divergence, the nine member equi merozoite antigen (EMA) superfamily, previously found as a multigene family only in T. equi, is also present in the novel parasite. Practically, significant sequence divergence in antigenic loci resulted in this undescribed Theileria sp. not being detectable using currently available diagnostic tests. Discovery of this novel species infective to equids highlights exceptional diversity within the genus Theileria, a finding with serious implications for apicomplexan parasite surveillance.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Introduction
ce:section.ce:para: Hemoparasites that cause life-long infection, such as those in the phylum Apicomplexa, are a major challenge for public and livestock health. Notorious examples include the arthropod-borne apicomplexan taxa Plasmodium and Babesia, for which infection in humans and cattle, respectively, result in malaria and bovine babesiosis, and theileriosis, which infects ruminants and equids (Kappmeyer et al., 2012), in addition to many other vertebrates. Discerning how apicomplexan protozoa emerge and persist in host populations is critical for controlling disease and transmission. Propagation of these organisms during long-term persistent infection results in genomic evolution that potentially impacts virulence, host range and reduced detectability (Hawley et al., 2013). The diversity of apicomplexans, especially Theileria, in wildlife is exceptional (Githaka et al., 2014; Mans et al., 2015). Vector-mediated movement of these organisms from wildlife to livestock can result in disease outbreaks that are not identifiable using current diagnostic assays. Data presented here document the molecular biology, genomic composition and phylogenetic placement of a newly discovered Theileria pathogen that has serious implications for diagnosis of Theileria infections in equids.

Equine piroplasmosis (theileriosis), caused by Theileria equi, is a tick-borne infection of equids for which control by vaccination is not currently available. Serological and nucleic acid-based diagnostic testing, followed by treatment of infected animals with imidocarb dipropionate (Ueti et al., 2012), is the method routinely used for transmission and disease control in non-endemic countries. Animal reservoirs for transmission include all equid species (Wise et al., 2013). Infection with T. equi can lead to a life-threatening anemia in the acute phase, and results in persistent infection in the chronic phase (Wise et al., 2013). Horses that survive the acute phase will be infected for life, with a parasitemia between 103 and 106 merozoites per mL of blood (Ueti et al., 2005), and thus serve as a reservoir for tick transmission. Since Theileria is not transmitted transovarially by the tick, ticks are not considered a generational reservoir. Although the United States (U.S.) is currently considered free of equine Theileria infection, recent detection of 20 infected horses in Florida, U.S. (Short et al., 2012) and 413 infected horses elsewhere, mostly in Texas, U.S. (Scoles et al., 2011), has increased awareness of the potential transmission and disease threats posed by asymptomatic Theileria infections (Ueti et al., 2005; Wise et al., 2014).

A stray horse, restrained at the U.S. – Mexico border, near Eagle Pass, Texas, was negative for T. equi by PCR, but borderline positive using a competitive ELISA (cELISA) (Knowles et al., 1991b). A hemoprotozoan parasite was recovered by whole blood transfer to a naïve splenectomized horse, and the genome sequenced. Based on parasite morphology and intra-erythrocytic replication, the parasite was identified as a species of Theileria. The implications of these data are discussed in the context of disease control of vector-borne apicomplexan parasites in general, but with specific reference to equine Theileria.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Materials and methods
Ethics statement
ce:section.ce:para: All animal experiments were approved by the University of Idaho, U.S., Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC), protocol numbers 2016–18, 2016–28 and 2016–29. The animal care and use protocol adhered to the Animal Welfare Act set forth under the U.S. Regulations and Standards in the Title 9 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Chapter 1, Subchapter A – Animal Welfare.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Horses (Equus ferus caballus)
ce:section.ce:para: This study utilized horses of various breeds and ages. The following horses were instrumental in work presented here. Three horses (H14, H16915 and H21490) were from the region of Eagle Pass, Texas. Seven additional horses, namely H196(S), H208(S), H270, H296, H233, H248(S) and H301(S), where (S) stands for “splenectomized”, were derived from a breeding herd located at the University of Idaho, under protocol number 2016–18. All whole blood transfers were carried out in citrate phosphate dextrose anticoagulant (Fenwal Inc., U.S.). H14 was the original source of blood. Splenectomized horse H208(S) received 120 mL of whole blood from H14. Two spleen-intact horses, H270 and H296, received 120 mL of whole blood from H16915 and H21490, respectively. Spleen-intact horse H233 received a 2 mL stabilate, with 12% parasitized erythrocytes (PPE), derived from H208(S). Stabilates were prepared as follows: whole blood was collected by jugular venipuncture into a vacuum flask containing 200 g of 5 mm glass beads and swirled until clotting occurred and blood defibrinated. Erythrocytes and plasma were transferred to conical centrifuge tubes and centrifuged at 1,400g for 10 min at 4 °C and plasma and buffy coat discarded. The erythrocyte pellet was washed four times in Puck’s Saline G solution (Life Technologies, U.S.) using 1,400g for 10 min at 4 °C centrifugation. An equal volume of 20% polyvinylpyrrolidone in Puck’s Saline G cryopreservative was added and aliquoted into cryogenic vials. Vials were frozen to −80 °C overnight and transferred to liquid nitrogen for permanent storage the next day. Splenectomized horses H248(S) and H301(S) received 120 mL of whole blood from H233. H196(S) was infected with T. equi™ (the reference T. equi Texas isolate) via intravenous inoculation with 120 mL of whole blood from horses maintained at the University of Idaho. Experimental horses received regular health checks from a licensed veterinarian. Prior to blood transfer, complete blood counts (CBCs) and serum chemistry panels were normal.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Comparative morphological analysis of asexual intra-erythrocytic forms of T. equi™ and parasite from H248(S)
ce:section.ce:para: A Nikon Upright Microscope Eclipse Ci, with calibrated scale, was used to measure parasite dimensions. Giemsa-stained blood slides were examined with a Nikon Plan Fluor at 100X/1.30 oil. The width and length of 40 individual masses from 10 Maltese crosses (Yokoyama et al., 2003), were measured for T. equi™ and the parasite from H248(S). The mean and standard deviation as well as the maximum width and length of individual Maltese cross masses were determined. The giemsa-stained blood slides were obtained from H248(S) and H196(S) infected with the new parasite or T. equi™, respectively (Scoles et al., 2011; Ueti et al., 2012). Theileria equi™ was chosen because it was obtained from the same region as the parasite derived from H248(S). Whole blood was collected from both H248(S) and H196(S) at 14 days p.i. Images were acquired using an Axio Imager M1 microscope (Carl Zeiss Microimaging, Thornwood, NY, USA) equipped with an LED bright field illuminator, Plan-Apochromat 63x/1.40 Oil M27 objective, AxioCam MRc5 digital camera, and AxioVision software (version 4.8.2.0; Carl Zeiss Microimaging, Thornwood, NY, USA). Images were exported in TIFF format and prepared for presentation using Photoshop Elements (version 5.0, Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA, USA).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Genomic sequencing and preliminary genome annotation
ce:section.ce:para: Parasite genomic DNA (gDNA) was obtained from infected red blood cells of H248(S) and was used to generate a 3 Kbp Illumina insert library. The gDNA was obtained using the Qiagen Blood and Cell Culture DNA Maxi Kit (Qiagen, U.S. catalog #13362) as per the manufacturer’s directions. This library was sequenced with Illumina technology to generate 100 bp-long mate-pair reads. Reads were filtered for adaptor sequence and quality trimmed with Trimmomatic v0.22 (http://www.usadellab.org/cms/?page=trimmomatic). Equine reads were identified by alignment to the EquCab2.0 genome assembly with bowtie2 (Langmead and Salzberg, 2012); read pairs with a mapq value greater than 30 were excluded from further analysis. The final filtered dataset contains 96,475,180 read pairs and 19,003,252,983 bases. The assembly was performed using Assembly By Short Sequences ABySS v1.3.3 k 64 (Simpson et al., 2009) with half of the reads input as linear reads (∼1,000× coverage), followed by scaffolding by SSPACE (http://www.baseclear.com/genomics/bioinformatics/basetools/SSPACE) using all mate-pair information. Further, additional gDNA, extracted from plugs of infected red blood cells from the same source as that used for the Illumina libraries, was used to construct a 15X coverage bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) library, which was arrayed in 384-well format. BAC clones were fingerprinted and end-sequenced, and used to improve scaffolding. The scaffolds were aligned to the genome assembly of T. equi (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/11168) using BLAST and manually annotated for order and orientation. The unknown hemoparasite scaffolds were tentatively assigned into chromosomes using this information (Table 1 ). Some of the remaining sequencing gaps were filled with Ns using GapFiller (http://www.baseclear.com/genomics/bioinformatics/basetools/gapfiller), when their predicted length between sequence read mates was identical to the homologous region in T. equi.

A preliminary annotation of the reconstructed chromosomes and the unanchored scaffolds was generated, including repeats and/or genes, using three approaches: (i) Maker software (Campbell et al., 2014); all expressed sequence tags (ESTs) from species in the order Piroplasmida, to which Theileria and Babesia belong, from GenBank were downloaded (50,343 sequences), assembled with cap3, and the resulting unigene of 11,641 transcripts fed into the Maker pipeline as EST evidence. All proteins of the Piroplasmida in GenBank (39,119 sequences) were used for protein homology evidence. Augustus (Hoff and Stanke, 2013) was run as part of the Maker pipeline, using the gene prediction model for Toxoplasma, the closest species provided as part of the Augustus package. (ii) GeneMark-ES (Borodovsky and Lomsadze, 2011), the program we have found to generate the most reliable de novo gene predictions for piroplasma genomes, and which does not require a training set. (iii) GMAP (Wu and Watanabe, 2005) was used to map the T. equi proteome onto the newly generated genome assembly of the parasite obtained from H248(S), followed by a series of in-house polishing scripts to merge genes with fragments split among contigs. The preliminary annotations generated by the three assemblers are currently being manually compared and validated to generate a combined, manually curated annotation. BAC clones covering areas of interest were further sequenced by directly sequencing off BAC DNA with standard dideoxy sequencing. Table 1 provides primer sets used for direct BAC sequencing verification of the presence or absence of ema gene family members predicted in the assembled sequence, together with accession numbers for derived sequences.

ce:section.ce:section-title: cELISA, and nested PCR (nPCR) for T. equi and parasite from H248(S)
ce:section.ce:para: The cELISA (Knowles et al., 1992) (VMRD, Inc.,U.S. catalog #274.2) for detection of equine antibody to T. equi was run according to the manufacturer’s recommendations. Samples are read in duplicate on a BioTek EPOCH2 microplate reader and the average is reported. A percent inhibition (PI) ≥40% is considered positive, with samples that average between 40% and 44% PI being considered borderline.

For nPCR testing, DNA was recovered from equine blood in isopropanol, washed in 70% ethanol, and resuspended in 50 μL of DNA hydration solution (10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5, Qiagen). DNA samples were tested for T. equi by targeting the single copy ema1 gene (Baptista et al., 2013). Primers for nPCR of the parasite derived from H248 were based on a 2,118 bp single-copy open reading frame (ORF) on chromosome 1 of the newly generated draft genome sequence for the species, which has no homology to sequences in other Theileria spp.: external-forward 5′ CCATACAACCCACTAGAG 3′, external-reverse 5′ CTGTCATTTGGGTTTGATAG 3′, internal-forward 5′ GACAACAGAGAGGTGATT 3′, and internal-reverse 5′ CGTTGAATGTAATGGGAAC 3′.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phylogenetic analyses: 18S rDNA-encoding gene
ce:section.ce:para: The sequence of the gene encoding the 18S rDNA was obtained from GenBank for the following taxa: T. equi, Theileria parva Muguga, Theileria annulata Spain2, Theileria orientalis, Babesia microti, Babesia bovis and Babesia bigemina (Supplementary Table S1). The 18S rDNA for some T. parva strains was reconstructed from whole genome sequence data reported in the literature: Katete, from Zambia (Geysen et al., 1999); the three component stocks within a widely used trivalent live vaccine cocktail, namely Kiambu 5 from Kenya, Muguga2 (a second Muguga clone of the original T. parva Muguga isolate), and Serengeti-transformed, from Tanzania (Norling et al., 2015); Marikebuni, from the Kenya coast, and Uganda, from northwestern Uganda (Henson et al., 2012). Finally, for the horse-infecting parasites described above (Section 2.2), the 18S sequence was directly amplified from gDNA, according to an established protocol (Bhoora et al., 2010). In short, forward primer NBabesia1F (5′ AAGCCATGCATGTCTAAGTATAAGCTTTT 3′) and reverse primer 18SRev-TB (5′ GAATAATTCACCGGATCACTCG 3′) were used in a primary PCR to amplify a fragment of 1600 bp in length. Reactions were performed in a final volume of 25 μl with High Fidelity PCR Master mix (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany), 0.2 mM of each primer and 2.5 μl of gDNA. The cycling conditions were: an initial denaturation of 2 min at 94 °C, followed by 40 cycles of 30 s at 94 °C, 45 s at 60 °C and 1 min at 72 °C, and a final extension of 7 min at 72 °C. All 18S amplicons have been deposited in GenBank (Supplementary Table S1).

Primer regions were trimmed from all sequences, and an alignment was generated with MAFFT v.7.245, (Katoh et al., 2005) with the following options: the Q-INS-i model alignment algorithm was used, default gap opening penalty and offset values were 1.53 and 0.0, respectively, the 200PAM/k = 2 matrix was used, and the option to leave regions containing gaps was invoked. Prior to phylogeny estimation, the nucleotide evolution model that best fit the data was determined with jModelTest v.2.1.7 (Darriba et al., 2012). Maximum likelihood (ML) phylogenetic analyses were conducted with RAxML v.8.2 (Stamatakis, 2014). An initial analysis using the autoMRE (extended majority-rule consensus tree criterion) option was used to determine a sufficient number of bootstrap (BS) replicates. Five subsequent independent analyses were executed utilizing the GTR model, each with different starting seed values for the random starting tree and BS replicates each called for 1,000 rapid BS replicates, followed by a search for the best-scoring ML tree. All analyses utilized a random starting tree as opposed to the default randomized stepwise-addition parsimony starting tree.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phylogenetic analyses equi merozoite antigen (EMA) multigene family
ce:section.ce:para: All EMA protein-encoding genes were obtained from the T. equi Florida isolate (Kappmeyer et al., 2012), T. parva (Gardner et al., 2005), T. annulata (Pain et al., 2005 ) and T. orientalis (Hayashida et al., 2013). Nine EMA homologs were identified in the annotation of the parasite derived from the H248(S) genome. The protein sequences were aligned with multiple alignment using fast fourier transform (MAFFT) as above, however, the MAFFT-G-INS-I model alignment algorithm and BLOSUM62 matrix (Henikoff and Henickof, 1992) were used. Prior to phylogeny estimation, the amino acid evolution model that best fit the data was determined with ProtTest v.3.2, (Guindon and Gascuel, 2003; Darriba et al., 2011). All 15 models of protein evolution were tested in addition to the gamma parameter (i.e. including models with rate variation among sites). The starting topology used for selection of the evolution model was based on an ML-reconstructed tree and tree topology optimization was invoked. Information criteria evaluated included Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), Second-Order Akaike (AICc), Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), and Decision Theory Criterion (DT). AICc and BIC sample sizes were determined by the total number of characters (alignment length). Phylogenetic relationships were estimated with RAxML as described above, however, the WAG + G model was employed.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Selection of high-confidence genes from parasite derived from H248(S).
ce:section.ce:para: For the purpose of phylogenetic reconstruction and divergence time estimation, we used two approaches to identify single-copy protein-coding genes in the Theileria haneyi n. sp. genome with one-to-one orthologs in T. equi: (i) from the 4,878 protein-coding genes predicted by GeneMark-ES, we selected all for which gene length was within 10% of the length of its ortholog in T. equi, resulting in a final subset of parasites derived from H248(S)-1 with 1,109 genes. (ii) The set of 5,357 genes predicted from GMAP was similarly parsed to identify genes similar in length to T. equi, resulting in a final subset of parasites from H248(S)-2 with 579 genes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification of homologs in piroplasma taxa
ce:section.ce:para: Homologs for all parasites derived from H248(S) proteins were identified in eight other piroplasma species: three species of Babesia, namely the re-annotated B. microti R1 strain (Silva et al., 2016), B. bovis T2Bo strain (Brayton et al., 2007), B. bigemina Bond strain (Jackson et al., 2014), and four Theileria spp., namely T. parva Muguga strain (Gardner et al., 2005), T. annulata Ankara strain (Pain et al., 2005), T. orientalis Shintoku strain (Hayashida et al., 2012) and T. equi FL strain (Kappmeyer et al., 2012). Clusters of eukaryotic orthologous genes (KOGs) were defined based on our comparative pipeline. Summarily, we used BLASTP to find matches among protein sequences within and between species, with the BLOSUM62 amino acid matrix, and an expected value cut-off of 10−5. Jaccard clustering was then performed twice, once to form within-species clusters of paralogous genes and a second time to derive a set of multi-species KOGs. In the first case, we used an 80% identity cut-off and a link score of 0.6. In the second, we set a Jaccard coefficient cut-off of 0 for edge pruning. Genes within a KOG were preliminarily aligned with ClustalW, with default parameters.

Phylogenetic analyses were conducted using the subset of predicted parasites derived from H248(S) nuclear genes which were identical, or nearly so, among the two predictions above (Section 2.8), such that for each locus the two predictions differed in protein sequence identity and length by ≤5%. We further restricted the set of genes to be used in phylogenetic analyses to homologs that are single copy genes in all piroplasma spp. used in the analyses. This resulted in a final set of 223 protein-coding single-copy genes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phylogeny reconstruction using nuclear loci
ce:section.ce:para: The placement of parasites derived from H248(S) was further analyzed based on 223 nuclear encoded proteins. Each of the 223 amino acid files was independently re-aligned with MAFFT, and best-fit models of amino acid substitution were independently determined for the 223 alignment files with ProtTest as described in Section 2.7.

Phylogenetic analyses were conducted with RAxML, as described in Section 2.6, based on the concatenated protein alignment files. The data were partitioned per protein, according to the best fitting model selected by ProtTest (CPREV + G, DAYHOFF + G, JTT + G, LG + G, RTREV + G, WAG + G), the gamma model of rate heterogeneity was applied to all partitions, and empirical amino acid frequencies were calculated for each partition. In addition to the ML analyses, a parsimony analysis was executed using PAUP* v.4.0b10 where all characters were treated as unordered and of equal weight, and gaps as missing characters (Wilgenbusch and Swofford, 2003). Accelerated transformation character-state optimization was used. Results from the five RAxML analyses were compared with one another and with the parsimony analysis.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Inference of divergence time between T. equi and parasite derived from H248(S)
ce:section.ce:para: Divergence time estimates were performed as described (Silva et al., 2015). Briefly, if amino acid sequence divergence for each protein is proportional to time, then the age of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of a species pair 1 (species 1a and 1b; eg T. parva and T. annulata) relative to the age of the MRCA of species pair 2 (species 2a and 2b; eg T. equi and parasite derived from H248(S)), can be determined from the ratio of the amino acid sequence divergence (d AA) between the species 1a and 1b by d AA for the same protein between species 2a and 2b. The optimal rate ratio between the two pairs of species, across all proteins, is estimated with Total Least Squares (TLS) regression (Silva et al., 2015). This method assumes that each protein evolves at a constant rate across the section of the tree of life being studied (i.e., constant rate across taxa), but different proteins can evolve at different rates. For this analysis, proteins encoded by single-copy genes shared by all four species were identified, and d AA was estimated between T. equi and the parasite derived from H248(S), and between T. parva and T. annulata (Supplementary Fig. S1). Only proteins for which the sequence length difference between orthologs in a species pair was at most 10% were used. For each species pair, hundreds to thousands of proteins were compared. For the T. equi-parasite derived from H248(S) comparison, analyses were done in parallel for both T. haneyi n. sp. genes annotated from aligning T. equi coding sequences (CDS) to the parasite derived from H248(S) genome assembly with GMAP, and for the GeneMark-ES ab initio gene predictions. The number of GeneMark-based parasite derived from H248(S) gene models that were similar in length to those in T. equi (n = 1,109) was twice as large as those generated with GMAP (n = 579), and therefore we proceeded only with the GeneMark-ES gene set for the calculations. Amino acid sequence divergence (d AA) was estimated using the JTT-F model of evolution implemented in the program codeml from the PAML package (Yang, 2007). Interactive Display for Evolutionary Analyses (IDEA) (Egan et al., 2008) was used to launch and monitor the PAML analyses and to distribute the computations across a computer grid.

These calculations resulted in an estimate of relative age of the MRCA of T. parva and T. annulata (in comparison with that of T. equi parasite derived from H248(S)). Absolute ages can then be estimated as follows: (1) estimate silent substitutions per site (d S) between the two species; (2) divide d S by the rate of substitution in silent sites, which is assumed to fall somewhere between the rates estimated for metazoans (∼8.1 × 10−9) and for invertebrates (1.5 × 10−8), and multiply by 106 to get divergence time in million years (MY); (3) finally, since the estimated divergence time has occured in two branches, leading from the MRCA to each extant taxon, divide divergence time by two to get the absolute time from the present to the MRCA of T. parva and T. annulata. The absolute age of the MRCA of the T. equi parasite derived from H248(S) can then be obtained from its known age relative to the age of the MRCA of T. parva and T. annulata.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Results
Phylogenetic analyses
ce:section.ce:para: Comparisons were made for the sets of trees for each of the five independent RAxML analyses for the 18S, EMA, and 223 nuclear encoding proteins by computing average relative Robinson Foulds distances between the topologies with RAxML. The five independent 18S analyses produced identical trees. The maximum likelihood RAxML trees for the 223 nuclear encoding proteins were identical to one another and to the parsimony tree resulting from the PAUP* analysis. The trees generated by RAxML for the analysis of EMA were also identical.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Discovery of a novel Theileria sp., T. haneyi n. sp.
ce:section.ce:para: Analysis of the 18S rDNA-encoding gene shows the sequence of the amplicon generated from this Theileria sp. clusters unambiguously with all other Theileria sequences, which together form a monophyletic clade (Fig. 1). The 18S rDNA sequence amplified from the infected horse found in Eagle Pass falls within a highly variable group of 18S rDNA sequences that have all been deposited in public databases under the umbrella term T. equi (Supplementary Table S2). In comparison, all 18S rDNA sequences from T. parva comprise a monophyletic clade, and share >99.5% nucleotide sequence identity, despite considerable genome-wide differences among the isolates from which they were obtained (Henson et al., 2012; Norling et al., 2015). These observations strongly suggest that many of the “T. equi” sequences in GenBank are misclassified and, in fact, likely represent a considerable number of hitherto undescribed Theileria spp. The 18S rDNA sequence of the Theileria sp. described here is only distantly related to that of the T. equi isolate from Florida (T. equiFL), the reference isolate (Fig. 1), supporting the hypothesis that they belong to two separate species. This assertion is further established by evidence presented below.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Designation of novel parasite as Theileria haneyi n. sp.
ce:section.ce:para: The first morphological evidence of differentiation of the undescribed Theileria sp. from T. equi TX is based on size differences among the erythrocytic, asexual (merozoite) stage (Fig. 2 ). The length and width of individual masses from the tetra-form Maltese cross (Yokoyama et al., 2003) revealed this stage to be significantly larger in T. equi TX (mean length 1.88 ± 0.21 µm and width 0.91 ± 0.13 µm) compared with Theileria sp. (mean length 1.15 ± 0.16 µm and width 0.70 ± 0.07 µm). The minimal and maximal lengths of individual Maltese cross masses are 1.57 µm and 2.32 µm, and 0.87 µm and 1.57 µm, for T. equi TX and Theileria sp., respectively. The minimal and maximal widths of the Maltese cross are 0.72 µm and 1.39 µm, and 0.56 µm and 0.9 µm, for T. equi TX and Theileria sp., respectively. The novel parasite was isolated from erythrocytes of an Equus ferus caballus restrained at the U.S. – Mexico border. The presence of additional susceptible hosts is unknown. While it is expected that Theileria sp. is transmissible by one or more tick vectors, specific vector(s) are unidentified. The related T. equi has a broad range of tick species that have been implicated or shown to be transmission vectors (Scoles and Ueti, 2015). Given the marked differences in morphology and 18S rDNA sequence between Theileria sp. and all other available Theileria spp., this new species is designated Theileria haneyi n. sp., isolate Eagle Pass. The genome of T. haneyi n. sp. hapantotype reported here was from DNA isolated from H248(S) and is stored and available as frozen stabilates which were prepared as described in Section 2.2. The T. haneyi n. sp. hapantotype exists in the intra-erythrocytic form (merozoite) of the Theileria life cycle.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification and characterization of ema family members in Theileria haneyi n. sp.
ce:section.ce:para: The EMA family of T. equi contains nine members and is part of a superfamily with single orthologs present in T. annulata, T. parva (Kappmeyer et al., 2012) and T. orientalis (Kim et al., 2017). Eight of the EMAs are similar in that they contain 273 to 286 amino acids, possess acidic (4.98–6.14) isoelectric points and have a range of 39.1% to 58.7% amino acid sequence identity to EMA-1. EMA-9 is truncated (16.4 kDa). The EMA superfamily was discovered through the search for conserved, immunodominant diagnostic antigens to improve diagnostic accuracy of T. equi infection in the horse (Knowles et al., 1992).

Genome sequencing of T. haneyi n. sp. was performed using parasite DNA obtained from a splenectomized horse H248(S), and the data was assembled using ABySS. After removal of short scaffolds (<2 Kb), the resulting genome assembly is 9.79 Mbp in length, significantly less than that of the T. equi reference strain, which is 11.79 Mbp (Kappmeyer et al., 2012). The assembly is highly fragmented, with the four nuclear chromosomes spread among 702 scaffolds, but the scaffold length of the assembly is comparable with the length of other fully assembled Theileria genomes, which range from 8 to 12 Mbp (Gardner et al., 2005; Pain et al., 2005, Kappmeyer et al., 2012), indicating that a nearly complete gene complement is present. Annotation of the T. haneyi n. sp. genome with Web Apollo revealed 4,878 putative protein-coding genes, considerably more than either T. parva or T. annulata, which have approximately 4,000 genes. Among these are nine members of the EMA multigene family, six of which are orthologues to those in the well-characterized equid parasite T. equi FL, with orthology defined by conserved synteny. The presence/absence of specific ema family members in the T. haneyi n. sp. genome was validated using a combination of primers and Sanger sequencing of a BAC clone library generated from genomic DNA (Table 1).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Divergence time between Theileria haneyi n. sp. and Theileria equi FL
Long-term persistence of Theileria haneyi n. sp.
ce:section.ce:para: To determine whether horses clear the infection rapidly or if, instead, they remain asymptomatic carriers, we monitored infected horses over a period of months. Splenectomized horse H208(S) developed a peak fever of 39.8 °C at 15 days p.i., 1.1 °C above normal (37.2–38.3 °C), and developed peak percent PPE of 12% at 16 days p.i. H208(S) was humanely euthanized at 17 days p.i. Infection with T. haneyi n. sp. was detected in two additional stray female horses (H16915 and H21490) in the Eagle Pass region by blood transfusions into spleen-intact horses H270 and H296. Fever was not detected in H270 or H296, and parasite levels remained below detection by light microscopy. A third spleen-intact horse, H233, was infected with T. haneyi n. sp. via a 2 mL 12% PPE stabilate derived from the splenectomized horse H208(S). H233 developed a peak fever of 39.4 °C 18 days p.i., but T. haneyi n. sp. also remained below detection by light microscopy. Infection of H270, H296 and H233 with T. haneyi n. sp. was confirmed by sequencing of 18S rDNA. Additional confirmation of infection in H233 was demonstrated by transfer of 120 mL of whole blood from H233 into each of two splenectomized horses H248(S) and H301(S). Whole blood was transferred to H248(S) 30 days p.i. of H233 and into H301(S) at 19 months p.i. of H233. H248(S) developed a peak fever of 39.1 °C at 29 days p.i., a peak PPE of 7.32% at 32 days p.i. and lowest packed cell volume (PCV) (10%) at 37 days p.i.. H301(S) developed a peak fever of 39.7 °C at 52 days p.i., a peak PPE of 1.08% at 30 days p.i. and lowest PCV (23%) at 51 days p.i. The ability of blood from H233 to transmit T. haneyi n. sp. to H248(S) and H301(S) after 30 days and 20 months, respectively, demonstrated persistent infection of H233. Table 3 provides a summary of donor and recipient blood transfer experiments and infection outcomes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Testing for T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp. infection by cELISA and nPCR
ce:section.ce:para: Horses H233 (42 months p.i.), H270 (19 months p.i.) and H296 (39 months p.i.) were tested using a commercially available cELISA for the presence of anti-T. equi antibodies to the epitope defined by the mAb36/133.97 (Knowles et al., 1991a). At the times tested, all three horses were negative by cELISA, remaining well below the cELISA positive cut-off of 40% inhibition (Supplementary Fig. S2). The cELISA kit positive control serum yielded 70% inhibition.

Given the inability to detect T. haneyi n. sp. infection (Supplementary Fig. S2), except for the borderline reactivity for H14 with the commercially available cELISA used for global detection of T. equi infection, a nested PCR (nPCR) specific for T. haneyi n. sp. was developed. The CDS of the gene from which the T. haneyi n. sp.-specific primers were derived does not have a homolog in T. equi, although it is in the genomic location occupied by ema1 within the T. equi genome. Theileria haneyi n. sp. -infected horses H233, H270 and H296, tested by nPCR with the designed primers, generated the expected 238 bp product and, as anticipated, the same horses were negative with the T. equi-specific primers (Baptista et al., 2013) and by cELISA (Supplementary Fig. S2). Conversely, uninfected horses and horses infected with T. equi were negative by nPCR using T. haneyi n. sp.-specific primers. Differentiation of these two species of Theileria in equids can therefore be accomplished unambiguously using nPCR.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Discussion
ce:section.ce:para: The data presented here provide evidence for the existence of a novel, cryptic Theileria species . The designation of this newly discovered species as T. haneyi n. sp., and not T. equi, is supported by: (i) phylogenetic analyses based on both 18S rDNA sequences and 223 nuclear-encoded protein-coding genes, (ii) extensive genome-wide differences, with predicted protein divergence between T. haneyi n. sp. and T. equi averaging 23% at the amino acid level, (iii) distinct immunological properties, and (iv) significant differences in cellular morphology. Analyses place the speciation event that gave rise to the lineages leading to two species at more than 33 million years ago.

Our data show that T. haneyi n. sp. is widespread in the Equidae, and suggest it has limited virulence in experimental infections. However, recent detection of 20 infected horses in Florida (Short et al., 2012) and 413 infected horses elsewhere, mostly in Texas (Scoles et al., 2011; Ueti et al., 2012) with the absence of clinical disease shows the lack of understanding concerning the pathogenesis and virulence of equine piroplasmosis. Also, the situation in mixed infections with other tick-transmitted pathogens in the field requires further investigation.

The serendipitous discovery of this parasite, which is provisionally named Theileria haneyi n. sp., highlights the role of genetic diversity in limiting detection of apicomplexan parasites of livestock. Life-long persistent infection through asexual reproduction in mammalian domestic and wildlife hosts, coupled with sexual reproduction in the tick vector, promotes dispersal among different mammalian hosts, thereby providing an environment that facilitates continuous evolution of the parasites, which are exposed to a distinct set of selective pressures from hosts and vectors. This can lead to potential changes in virulence, transmissibility, detectability and immunogenicity. Due to limited surveillance capacity and increased anthropogenically mediated animal movement globally, wildlife reservoirs of persistent infectious diseases pose an increasing risk of spread of new diseases to livestock, with the result that existing diagnostic tests may not be adequate. The phylogenetic relationship of T. haneyi n. sp. to Theileria spp. from waterbuck, which is a ruminant (Githaka et al., 2014), and from several equids, including horses and zebra from South Africa, raises questions concerning its route of transmission to the American continent, and the implications for the epidemiology of Theileria infections in equids on a global scale.

Comparison of rDNA sequences classified as T. equi from multiple locations worldwide indicates greater variation than expected within a single species (Hall et al., 2013; Mans et al., 2015; Peckle et al., 2018), and suggests that multiple taxa are likely to be involved including additional, so far undescribed, species. The 18S rDNA reported from the Texas border (Hall et al., 2013) is T. haneyi n. sp. Furthermore, studies comparing 18S rDNA sequences supported dividing T. equi into two or three distinct clades (Peckle et al., 2018). As shown here, the extraordinary amount of sequence diversity among “T. equi” 18S rDNA sequences is much higher than the divergence found in the 18S rDNA locus between Theileria parva and Theileria annulata. This is strongly supported by comparison of the divergence in predicted proteins derived from the complete genome sequences. Theileria equi FL and T. haneyi n. sp. differ at the protein level more than do T. parva and T. annulata, which are distinguished by tick vector, pathology, mammalian host cell preference and geographical distribution. Given the high degree of genomic differentiation between T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp., it will be of interest to sequence the complete genomes of other apicomplexan parasites currently classified as “T. equi” in GenBank, but that differ from T. equi and from T. haneyi n. sp. in their 18S rDNA sequence.

Comparative genomics of T. equi FL, (Kappmeyer et al., 2012) and T. haneyi n. sp. provides insights into the evolution of the T. equi merozoite antigen (ema) gene family. This family now has 12 known members and is part of a superfamily with single copy homologues in T. annulata and T. parva (Kappmeyer et al., 2012), and T. orientalis (Kim et al., 2017). While it remains unclear whether the maintenance of a specific number of ema copies per genome is significant, it is noteworthy that both T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp. both contain nine copies, despite the fact that only six are orthologous between species. Importantly, since only one strain (Eagle Pass) of T. haneyi n. sp. was sequenced, it is not known if other isolates maintain the same number or sequence comparisons of the EMA family found within T. haneyi n. sp. (Eagle Pass).

The work described herein demonstrates that T. haneyi n. sp. is undetectable using current surveillance tools that target EMA-1 of the immunodominant EMA superfamily. EMA-1 and EMA-2 share an epitope as defined by mAb36/133.97 (Knowles et al., 1991a). Horses infected with T. haneyi n. sp. yield negative results when using the commercial cELISA for T. equi. The reason that the index horse (H14), the basis of the initial discovery of T. haneyi n. sp., yielded a borderline positive in the T. equi cELISA, is unknown. This finding is perplexing since none of the experimentally infected horses were positive in the cELISA. Possibilities for the borderline positive in the index horse include a false positive test or co-infection of H14 with T. equi. The latter is unlikely since blood transferred from H14 to H208(S) detected only T. haneyi n. sp. Although antigenic cross-reactivity among the EMAs may be possible, shared epitopes in addition to those recognized by mAb36/133.97 have not been detected. The absence of ema1 in the T. haneyi n. sp. genome and cELISA data in horses experimentally infected with T. haneyi n. sp. (Supplementary Fig. S2) support the absence of the epitope recognized by mAb36/133.97 within T. haneyi n. sp. gene products.

Although data shown here indicate T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp. are phylogenetically distinct, the data also indicate that they share pathogenesis traits in equids, including intra-erythrocytic merozoite replication and erythrocyte lysis (Knowles et al., 1994). However, the limited pathogenesis data presented here does not allow an accurate determination of virulence for T. haneyi n. sp. compared with T. equi. Although T. haneyi replication led to fever, high acute parasitemia and decreased PCV in splenectomized horses, clinical disease in horses possessing a spleen was minimal. Factors contributing to virulence in T. equi infections have not been defined. This is demonstrated by recent detection of numerous horses infected with T. equi on two separate occasions (Scoles et al., 2011; Short et al., 2012; Ueti et al., 2012). For instance, 292 horses were discovered to be infected with T. equi on a ranch from Kleberg County, Texas; however only one Quarter horse mare was recognized as having clinical signs, which were not life threatening (Scoles et al., 2011; Ueti et al., 2012). Virulence is a dependent variable that is “a host-centered measure of a phenomenon that is neither host nor parasite but results from host parasite complex” (Casadevall and Pirofski, 2001; Poulin and Combes, 1999). These data help to explain the previous failure to detect T. haneyi n. sp. It will be of interest to examine whether co-infection with these two parasites occurs naturally and whether infection with T. haneyi n. sp. modulates the pathogenesis and chemotherapeutic treatment of T. equi.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Taxonomic summary
ce:section.ce:para: Theileria haneyi n. sp. Knowles & Kappmeyer (Alveolata: Apicompaxa: Hematozoa: Piroplasmida).
Description: erythrocyte bodies vary from immature spherical (ring form) to mature pyriform with occasional Maltese crosses containing 4 mature pyriforms (Mehlhorn and Schein, 1998).
Type host: domesticated horse (Equus ferus caballus).
Additional hosts: not known.
Type locality: Eagle Pass, Texas, United States of America Latitude: 28°42.5484′ N Longitude: 100°29.9712′ W.

Other localities: U.S.A.: Florida, Georgia, and Texas. Mexico: Feral horses (H14), (H16915) and (H21490) entered at Eagle Pass, Texas. Second horse from Mexico(N) spent time in Mexico City and subsequently in Juárez, Chihuahua.

Location in host: T. haneyi n. sp. persist in erythrocytes. Prepatent period: prepatent period under natural transmission is not known. In blood transfer studies, prepatent period highly variable ranging from 14 to 30 days in splenectomized horses. Prepatent period unknown in spleen intact horses.
Patent period: Variable in splenectomized horses (14 to 30 days) and unknown in spleen intact horses.
Pathogenicity studies: not performed.

Material deposited: EaglePass248 strain deposited as blood stabilate and genomic DNA at the Animal Disease Research Unit, ARS-USDA, Pullman, Washington, U.S. GenBank accession numbers for type strain (LAPW01000001 – LAPW01000009).
ZooBank LSID:urn:lsid:zoobank.org:pub:B915F0DA-168F-4A12-A6A3-75E40D784D76.
Etymology: Species is named in recognition of Darrell Haney, a veterinarian working in Eagle Pass, Texas, who first detected this organism.

Diagnosis: Differentiation of T. haneyi n. sp. from T. equi is based on size differences among the erythrocytic, asexual (merozoite) Maltese cross stage (Fig. 2). The length and width of individual masses from the tetra-form Maltese cross (Yokoyama et al., 2003) revealed this stage to be significantly larger in T. equi (mean length 1.88 ± 0.21 µm and width 0.91 ± 0.13 µm) compared with T. haneyi n. sp. (mean length 1.15 ± 0.16 µm and width 0.70 ± 0.07 µm). The minimal and maximal lengths of individual Maltese cross masses are 1.57 µm and 2.32 µm, and 0.87 µm and 1.57 µm, for T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp., respectively. Minimal and maximal widths of the Maltese crosses are 0.72 µm and 1.39 µm, and 0.56 µm and 0.9 µm, for T. equi and T. haneyi n. sp., respectively. Differentiation of infection by T. equi from T. haneyi is accomplished by targeting the single copy T. equi ema1 gene, and a unique T. haneyi n. sp. 2,118 base pair open reading frame by nested PCR. Primers for nested PCR based on the genomic sequence of T. haneyi n. sp. were derived from this 2,118 bp single copy open reading frame on chromosome 1 of T. haneyi n. sp., that is unique to this species: external-forward 5′ CCATACAACCCACTAGAG 3′, external-reverse 5′ CTGTCATTTGGGTTTGATAG 3′, internal-forward 5′ GACAACAGAGAGGTGATT 3′, and internal-reverse 5′ CGTTGAATGTAATGGGAAC 3′.
